data.title: Fix build error on VS2017.
data.body:
Fix a build error on Windows/VS2017 that was introduced in commit `3528b1e571dee24917b0141232f135e29bf088ba`: `_chmod` is defined with return type `Error` but the default implementation returns nothing. 

The `_chmod` function is used in `DirAccess::copy` so it cannot be declared in `FileAccessUnix` (where it would belong IMHO). Initially I changed `FileAccess::_chmod` to a pure virtual function, but then I had to add multiple implementations that do the same thing (e.g., in `FileAccessNetwork` or `FileAccessWindows`). I'm not happy with either solution so I went for the less intrusive one, but I can modify the PR if desired.

data.title: Code in worker thread suddenly starts executing on the main thread
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Ubuntu 16.04, Godot 2.1.4.

**Issue description:**

It seems that accessing variables through an array shared between the main thread and a worker thread somehow causes code in the worker thread to start executing on the main thread...? I'm not sure exactly what's going on under the hood; I just see that the result is that my worker thread code is now operating on the main thread, causing jank when intensive calculations are run.

```gdscript
extends Node


var calc_thread = Thread.new()
var mutex = Mutex.new()

var request_queue = []

class PathRequest:
	var start_pos
	var end_pos

func _ready():
	calc_thread.start(self, "_process_requests")
	set_process(true)

func request_path(pathfinder, start_pos, end_pos):
	var pr = PathRequest.new()
	pr.start_pos = start_pos
	pr.end_pos = end_pos

	mutex.lock()
	request_queue.append(pr)
	mutex.unlock()

func _process_requests(parameters):
	while true:
		mutex.lock()
		var request
		var request_count = request_queue.size()
		if request_count > 0:
			request = request_queue[0]
			request_queue.pop_front()
		mutex.unlock()
                # The following loop was used to verify that the thread was running independently;
                # eg, does not lock up the main thread. An infinite loop does not lock up the main thread
                # at this point:
                # while true:
                #    pass

		if request != null:
			print("Processing request: ", request)
                        # This code used to be pathfinding resolution code
                        # But has been removed to simplify the scenario.
                        # The following two lines freezes the main thread:
			while true:
				pass
```

If I never interrogate an object from `request_queue`, then the thread continues on its way merrily.

**Steps to reproduce:**

- Create node
- Add array to node as member variable
- Add thread to node as member variable
- Start thread in `_ready()`
- From the main thread, push items into array (use mutex)
- From the "worker" thread, read an item from that array (use mutex)
- Use item in an if statement (checking to see if one if its members is not null, etc)
- Experience jank, because code following the if statement is now executing(?) on main thread

data.title: Various GDScript performance tweaks
data.body:
As a preparation for other performance enhancements to GDScript:call() start by removing more of the GDScript runtime checks on release.

This code has been tested with 2d/platformer, 3d/platformer, 3d/materials_test, and goltorus. No regressions were found.

For the people watching at home, the reason for doing this first is so that I can test part of the new control flow necessary for a faster execution loop for GDScript opcode dispatching.

I've also identified Variant::reference() as a bottleneck for tight loops. I've added a check that will prevent Variant from clearing itself in situations where it is not necessary.

Speed difference before and after 
Before: Time taken: 50952
After (removing checks): Time taken: 37515 (73% compared to baseline)
After (also speeding up reference): Time taken: 28203 (55% compared to baseline)

for this PR for the following code:
```gdscript
func _ready():
        var time_before = OS.get_ticks_msec()

        var c
        for i in range(10000000):
                var next
                var first = 1
                var second = 2
                for c in range(40):
                        next = first + second
                        first = second
                        second = next
                c = next
        print(c)

        var total_time = OS.get_ticks_msec() - time_before
        print("Time taken: " + str(total_time))
        get_tree().quit()
        pass
```

By request some comparisons with Python 2 and 3

Python2: Time taken: 17.2206029892 (60% compared to this PR)
Python3: Time taken: 20.676743745803833 (73% compared to this PR)

For the following code:
```python
import time

def main():
    start = time.time()

    c = 0
    for i in range(10000000):
            first = 1
            second = 2
            for c in range(40):
                    next = first + second
                    first = second
                    second = next
            c = next
    print(c)

    end = time.time()
    print("Time taken: " + str(end - start))


main()
```

data.title: Error running basic html5 build in chrome: 'sampler2DArray' : No precision specified
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Linux Mint 18 Sarah
Godot_v3.0-alpha1_x11.64
GPU: Nvidia GeForce GTX 750 Ti
GPU driver: nvidia-375.74-0ubuntu1

**Issue description:**
Game doesn't run in html5 (tried both WebAssembly and asm.js) because an error appears.

> **ERROR**: At: drivers/gles3/shader_gles3.cpp:167:_display_error_with_code() - SceneShaderGLES3: Fragment Program Compilation Failed:
> test-export.html:278 ERROR: 0:78: 'sampler2DArray' : No precision specified

[Full stack trace](https://pastebin.com/96m1vMvg)

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a basic scene with a MeshInstance (cube), Camera and OmniLight
2. Compile to Html5 with WebAssembly or asm.js option selected
3. Run a php local webserver in the exported folder with php -S localhost:8000
4. Open localhost:8000 in Chrome
5. Loading appears, then an error in the console

![screenshot_20170918_144825](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2841740/30561405-89ec3760-9c80-11e7-94d5-f0aec2b6b762.png)

**Link to minimal example project:**
[3d-test.tar.gz](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1311999/3d-test.tar.gz)

data.title: Add more useful 3D viewport rendering modes
data.body:
Now that Godot includes [a wireframe mode for the 3D viewport](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/180032/30556362-e57c2336-9caa-11e7-859c-008b9f82f994.png), more viewport rendering modes could be added for the convenience of developers and artists alike.

## Outline mode

![Outline mode example](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/180032/30556407-0d331c04-9cab-11e7-85a5-7e0443160779.png)

This mode displays materials as usual, but displays a wireframe *on top* of them. The color should be settable by the user, but probably should default to a white or light gray color.

**Example use case:** Displaying geometry complexity while still being able to freelook through a level easily.

## Lighting mode

![Lighting mode example](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/180032/30556373-ebd30042-9caa-11e7-8ccd-9a3890bb1549.png)

This mode sets the normal map strength of all materials to 0, sets the albedo texture and color to pure white (`#ffffff`), disables specularity, sets roughness to 1 and metallic to 0.

**Example use case:** Analyzing lighting conditions in a level, regardless of the applied materials.

___

*Footnote: the screenshots come from [Cube 2: Sauerbraten](http://sauerbraten.org/), I am not working on an implementation of these modes in Godot.*

data.title: Running a game sometimes only shows project manager window
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Windows 10 (1703) x64
Godot v3.0.alpha_custom_build.bc005a5

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
Sometimes when running a project, godot can't find the project.godot file, and just shows the project manager instead of the actual game. This seems to happen randomly, sometimes a few times in a row, sometimes just once. Running godot editor as admin doesn't change anything, as well as moving the project to different locations (like c:\users\... or another drive)

Console output:
** Debug Process Started **
Couldn't open C:\dev\godot\bin/godot.windows.opt.tools.64.pck
Couldn't open godot.windows.opt.tools.64.pck
Couldn't load/find C:/Users/Christian/godottest/test_project/project.godot or project.binary
Couldn't load/find C:/Users/Christian/godottest/project.godot or project.binary
Couldn't load/find C:/Users/Christian/project.godot or project.binary
Couldn't load/find C:/Users/project.godot or project.binary
Couldn't load/find C://project.godot or project.binary

GLES3: max ubo reflections: 455, ubo size: 144
WARNING: not found: gdnative/singletons
SVG_GENERATION TIME: 0.084

I also sometimes get errors like this one, maybe it's related. On my game project the error lists my project.godot file most of the time, and once it appeared, it is shown on nearly every time I try to run the game. :

- try running it a few times in a row

data.title: Misplaced and glitchy shadows for all lights
data.body:
Windows 10, Godot 3.0 master 09/17/2017, AMD Radeon HD 7770
Antergos (Arch), Godot 3.0 master 09/17/2017, Intel HD 4000

**Issue description:**
Godot aims to have an state of the art renderer on par with other actual engines and at the same time become an "easy to use" tool. We have a problem with the shadows for quite a long time  that goes against that goals.

All the lights produce shadows out of place (out of the box) and adjusting the bias to right place creates glitches.

**1. Omni Light** 

- Cube : 
The default bias is [0.1](https://imgur.com/ntcF9DS)5 but the shadows are on place with bias around [0.02-0.04](https://imgur.com/EGZ70OO).  The position of the shadows between editor and ingame are different. The shadows in the correct position show glitches in both editor and in game.

- Paraboloid:
The default bias is [0.15](https://imgur.com/S4qxxic) but the shadows are _almost_ on place with bias
[around 0](https://imgur.com/T4xFy6W). With this value glitches are shown both editor and in game. The position of the shadows between editor and ingame are different. With paraboloid it's imposible to get the shadows exactly in its correct place.

**2. Spot Light**

The default [bias is 0.15](https://imgur.com/8ZyOp5T) but the shadows are on place with bias [around 0](https://imgur.com/IkssMVV). With this bias, artifacts show up in the editor but look fine in game.

**3. Directional Light**

The default [shadow bias is 0.1 and the light default normal bias is 0.8](https://imgur.com/8ZyOp5T) but the shadows are _almost_ on place with bias [around 0 and light normal bias <= 0.20](https://imgur.com/8kkRiOG).  This values get artifacts on the editor and in game. In this type of light the amount of gliches in game change depending of the [resizing of the window](https://imgur.com/JgXn0Qj). It's imposible to get the shadows exactly in its correct place without big amounts of artifacts.


_For the "ease to use" aproach we cant just force the user to search the value of the shadow bias to put the shadow where it should be from the begining._

_From the "state of the art renderer" perspective, we need to have shadows that look ok, with an aceptable resolution out of the box and the users should be able to get the correct place for shadows without artifacts._

**Steps to reproduce:**
Just loading an asset and putting any king of light shows this issue, but you can activate/deactivate the types of lights in the demo attached to see the bias behaviour.

**Link to minimal example project:**
[lightBiasTests.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1310515/lightBiasTests.zip)

data.title: Implement headless (server) version for all desktop platforms
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version:**
All desktop platforms, master branch (7bd0067).

**Issue description:**
The current headless version of Godot (no rendering, no audio), a.k.a. the "server" platform, is Linux-specific (`platform=server`).

The dummy rasterizer and dummy audio servers are however platform-independent, and only the [windows management code is platform-specific](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/6059#issuecomment-238195785).

We should eventually replace the server platform by a `server=yes` compilation switch that would apply to all desktop platforms where it makes sense (Linux, macOS, Windows).

data.title: Be type-strict checking on equality checks
data.body:
After a short discussion with @reduz and @karroffel we decided to make
all non number/number comparisons return type errors on comparisons.

Now bool == bool is allowed but Vector2 == Vector3 is a type error and
no longer 'not equal'. The same has been done for the != operators.

In addition I forgot to add some failures to some Object operators
meaning that there was a potential for a crasher.

This PR also includes a fix for booleanization pointed out by @jjay. The code
```gdscript
var x = Dictionary()
if not x:
  print("empty dict")
```
is now valid GDScript

This fixes #11411

data.title: Scaling problems on Android
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Godot bc005a57d38137b062e0ccc26467353f53556930, Samsung Galaxy S6 (Android 7.0)

**Issue description:**

See how scaled screen looks like on [Android (bad)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2417849/30807974-5b51b5d2-a226-11e7-92b7-899af73a58c2.png) vs [macOS (ok)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2417849/30807975-5c830848-a226-11e7-8102-b2b6a156cfc5.png) with the same project.

![Android (bad)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2417849/30807974-5b51b5d2-a226-11e7-92b7-899af73a58c2.png)
![macOS (ok)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2417849/30807975-5c830848-a226-11e7-8102-b2b6a156cfc5.png)

**Steps to reproduce:**

```bash
git clone -b 2d-scale-bug https://github.com/endragor/etc2bug.git 2d-scale-bug
cd 2d-scale-bug
godot --export-debug Android test.apk
```

Then install and open `test.apk` on the device.

data.title: Copy the viewport camera's transform to a selected node
data.body:
Please add the ability for me to set a selected node's transform to match the current viewport camera's transform.

This could be a shortcut that works universally for any node activated by:
- A default keyboard shortcut (could be **ctrl+t** for transform? appears to be currently unused)
- A button in the toolbar above the viewport

Expected usage:

- Select any node in the scene tree
- Position your viewport camera (using the already implemented free-look features) to where you want the node's new transform
- Activate the shortcut to copy the transform from the viewport camera to the selected node

Result:
- The selected node would now be in the same position, with the same rotation as the viewport camera.
- Any geometry associated with the selected node would now be encasing the viewport camera.
- Scale should probably be left untouched. _Edit: Perhaps the wording of this issue should use Translation and Rotation instead of Transform._

Use case:
- Positioning a Camera node above and looking at a character
- Compositing scene objects to face one another
